case_name: Income-tax Officer, Central Circle 1, Delhi v. H.U.F. M/s. Rai Singh Deb Singh Bist

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 2392 to 2403 of 1969

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 23 92 to 2403 of 1969.

facts.text: Appeals by certificate from judgment and order dated September 9, 1968 of Delhi High Court in Civil Writs Nos. 67 to 78 of 1968

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by certificate from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1968 of the Delhi High Court at New Delhi in Civil Writs Nos. 67 to 78 of 1968.

facts.text: Delhi High Court allowed writ petitions and quashed impugned notices

anchor.surface_text: The High Court of Delhi allowed those writ petitions and quashed the impugned numberices. Hence these appeals.

facts.text: Writ petitions filed by H.U.F. Ms. Rai Singh Deb Singh Bist and Karta Thakur Mohan Singh Bist challenging notices under s. 34(1)(a) of Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 issued by ITO Central Circle 1 Delhi

anchor.surface_text: These appeals by certificate arise from several writ petitions filed by the H.U.F. M s. Rai Singh Deb Singh Bist and its Karta Thakur Mohan Singh Bist, challenging the validity of certain numberices issued under s. 34 1   a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  in short the Act  by the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle 1, Delhi.

facts.text: Assessee is H.U.F.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee in these cases is an H.U.F.

facts.text: Assessment years range from 1942-43 to 1953-54

anchor.surface_text: The assessment years with which we are companycerned in these appeals range from 1942-43 to 1953-54.

facts.text: Assessee filed returns for these years in due time

anchor.surface_text: The assessee filed its returns for these years in due time.

facts.text: Assessee's account books showed considerable cash credits in name of brothers-in-law of the Karta who were living in Nepal

anchor.surface_text: The assessees account-books showed companysiderable cash credits in the name of the brothers-in-law of the 2nd respondent, the Karta of the U.F. Those alleged creditors were living in Nepal.

facts.text: Account books showed credit entries in name of Rana Anand Nar Singh in connection with expenses for getting trees cut on behalf of assessee

anchor.surface_text: The account books also showed certain credit entries in the name of Rana Anand Nar Singh, alleged to be in companynection with expenses incurred by him for getting trees cut on behalf of the assessee.

facts.text: Assessee was a forest contractor and had taken large tracts of forests for felling trees in Nepal

anchor.surface_text: The assessee was a forest companytractor. He had taken large tracts of forests for felling trees in Nepal.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer investigated genuineness of cash credit entries and alleged amount due to one of them

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer went into the genuineness of the cash credit entries standing in the name of the alleged creditors of the assessee as well as to the alleged amount due to one of them.

facts.text: Assessee's contention regarding cash credits substantially accepted by Appellate Assistant Commissioner or Revenue Appellate Tribunal

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the assessee was substantially accepted either by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner or by the Revenue Appellate Tribunal.

facts.text: Final assessments for 1943-44 to 1949-50 made pursuant to settlement between assessee and Deputy Director of Inspection Investigation New Delhi on October 18, 1954

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the assessment for the assessment years 1943-44 to 1949-50, the final assessments were made in pursuance of an agreement or settlement arrived at between the assessee and the Deputy Director of Inspection  Investigation  New Delhi on October 18, 1954

facts.text: Income-tax Officer issued notices under s. 34(1)(a) long after assessments finalised to reopen them

anchor.surface_text: Long after the assessments in question were final- ised, the Income-tax Officer. issued numberices to the appellants under s. 34 1   a  of the Act seeking to reopen the assessments already finalised.

facts.text: In writ petitions assessee alleged no relevant material before Income-tax Officer to believe income escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, the assessee alleged in his writ petitions that there was numberrelevant material before the Income-tax Officer before he issued numberices under s. 34  1   a  on the basis of which he companyld have had reason to believe that any income had escaped assessment.

facts.text: Assessee called upon Income-tax Officer to produce report to Central Board of Revenue and CBR order in writ petitions

anchor.surface_text: In the writ petitions the assessee called upon the Income-tax Officer to produce the report made by him to the Central Board of Revenue as well as the order of the Central Board of Revenue thereon.

facts.text: Union of India and Income-tax Officer did not produce the report or CBR order

anchor.surface_text: Despite this prayer, neither the Union of India number the Income-tax Officer cared to produce the report made by the Income-tax Officer to the Central Board of Revenue under s. 34 1   a  or the order of the Central Board of Revenue.

facts.text: Before hearing of writ petitions assessee applied to court to call for documents; affidavit filed stating relevant records could not be traced from CBR file

anchor.surface_text: Before the hearing of the writ petitions companymenced, the assessee again applied to the Court to call upon the Union of India and the Income-tax Officer to produce those documents. In response to that application, an affidavit was filed before the Court stating that the relevant records companyld number be traced from the file of the Central Board of Revenue.

facts.text: No reason given for not producing copies from Income-tax Officer file

anchor.surface_text: Assuming that the companycerned records were missing from the file of the Central Board of Revenue, the companyy of the report made by the Income-tax Officer and the order received by him must have been in the file of the Income-tax Officer. No reason was given for number producing those records.

facts.text: Department contended that in 1955 assessee sold large tracts of land to two brothers-in-law for Rs. 47 lakhs but property was not worth that amount

anchor.surface_text: All that was said on behalf of the department was that some- time in the year 1955, the assessee sold large tracts of land to two of his brothers in-law for a sum of Rs. 47 lakhs but in reality that property was number worth that amount.

facts.text: Cash credit entries were brought to notice of Income-tax Officer before relevant assessment orders passed

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier the cash credit entries were brought to the numberice of the Income-tax Officer before the relevant assessment orders were passed.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer had occasion to investigate cash credit entries

anchor.surface_text: He had an occasion to investigate into them.
s. 34 1   a  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922  in short the Act  by the Income-tax Officer, Central Circle 1, Delhi.

concepts.interpretation: Provision allowing ITO to reopen assessments if there is reason to believe income escaped due to assessee's omission or failure to disclose fully and truly all material facts; requires recording of reasons and CBR satisfaction.

anchor.surface_text: Further, before doing so, he must have recorded his reasons for acting under s. 34 1   a  and the Central Board of Revenue must have been satisfied on those reasons that it is a fit case for the issue of the numberice. The recording of the reasons in support of the belief formed by the Income-tax Officer and the satisfaction of the Central Board of Revenue on the basis of the reasons recorded by the Income-tax Officer that it is a fit case for issue of numberice under s. 34  1   a  are extremely important circumstances to find out whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to proceed under s. 34 1   a .

concepts.unlisted_label: Satisfaction of Central Board of Revenue
concepts.unlisted_description: Precondition for s.34(1)(a) notice; must be based on examination of recorded reasons.

anchor.surface_text: In Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Com- panies District 1. Calcutta and anr.  1  this Court laid down  1  that to confer jurisdiction under s. 34 to issue numberice in respect of assessments beyond the period of four years, but within a period of eight years, from the end of the relevant year, two companyditions had to be satisfied. The first was that the Income-tax Officer must have reason to believe that income, profits or gains chargeable to income- tax had been under assessed. The second was that he must also have reason to believe that such under-assessment had occurred by reason of either  1  omission or failure on the part of an assessee to make a return of his income under section 22, or  2  omission or failure on the part of an assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for that year. Both these companyditions are companyditions precedent to be satisfied before the Income-tax Officer companyld have jurisdiction to issue a numberice for the assessment or re-assessment beyond the period  1 41 I.T.R. 191. of four years but within the period of eight years from the end of the year in question.

concepts.interpretation: Two conditions precedent: (1) reason to believe under-assessment; (2) due to non-disclosure or non-filing.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for the years in question, income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax

anchor.surface_text: In Chhugamal Rajpal v. S. P. Chaliha and ors.  1  this Court ruled that before an Income-tax Officer can be said to have had reason to believe that some income had escaped assessment, he should have some relevant material before him from which he companyld have drawn the inference that income has escaped assessment. His vague feeling that there might have been some escape of income from assessment is number sufficient.

concepts.interpretation: Reason to believe must be founded on relevant material enabling inference of escapement; vague suspicion insufficient.

issues.text: The validity of those notices [issued under s. 34(1)(a) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922]

anchor.surface_text: The validity of those notices is in issue.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had reason to believe that by reason of omission or failure on the part of an assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment, income had escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: under s. 34  1    a , he must have reason to believe that by reason of omission or failure on the part of an assessee to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for his assessment for the years in question, income, profits or gains chargeable to income-tax have escaped assessment during those years.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer recorded his reasons for acting under s. 34(1)(a) and the Central Board of Revenue was satisfied on those reasons that it was a fit case for issuing the notice

anchor.surface_text: Further, before doing so, he must have recorded his reasons for acting under s. 34 1   a  and the Central Board of Revenue must have been satisfied on those reasons that it is a fit case for the issue of the notice.

issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to proceed under s. 34(1)(a)

anchor.surface_text: The recording of the reasons in support of the belief formed by the Income-tax Officer and the satisfaction of the Central Board of Revenue on the basis of the reasons recorded by the Income-tax Officer that it is a fit case for issue of notice under s. 34  1   a  are extremely important circumstances to find out whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to proceed under s. 34 1   a .

issues.text: Whether there was relevant material before the Income-tax Officer on the basis of which he could have had reason to believe that income had escaped assessment due to the assessee's non-disclosure

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case, the assessee alleged in his writ petitions that there was no relevant material before the Income-tax Officer before he issued notices under s. 34  1   a  on the basis of which he could have had reason to believe that any income had escaped assessment.

issues.text: Whether the facts necessary to confer jurisdiction on the Income-tax Officer to proceed under s. 34(1)(a) had been established

anchor.surface_text: Under these circumstances, it is not possible to come to the conclusion that the facts necessary to confer jurisdiction on the Income-tax Officer to proceed under s. 34 1   a  had been established.

issues.text: Whether there was any relevant material before the Income-tax Officer before issuing notices under s. 34(1)(a) to have reason to believe that as a result of the assessee's failure to fully and truly disclose facts, income escaped assessment

anchor.surface_text: there is nothing to show that there was any relevant material before the Incometax Officer before he issued the notices under S. 34  1   a  to-have reason to believe that as a result of the assessees failure to state in its return truly and fully any fact, any income had escaped assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Department failed to produce records of ITO's reasons and CBR satisfaction despite requests and court directions; adverse inference drawn that records unfavorable; no other material shown satisfying conditions precedent from Calcutta Discount precedent.

holdings.text: These circumstances give rise to an adverse inference against the department. We are constrained to come to the conclusion that the records in question were not produced because they did not assist the departments case.

anchor.surface_text: These circumstances give rise to an adverse inference against the department. We are constrained to come to the conclusion that the records in question were not produced because they did not assist the departments case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Repeated prayers in writ petitions and applications to produce ITO's report to CBR and CBR order not complied with; affidavit claimed records missing from CBR file but no explanation for absence from ITO file.

holdings.text: there is nothing to show that there was any relevant material before the Incometax Officer before he issued the notices under S. 34  1   a  to-have reason to believe that as a result of the assessees failure to state in its return truly and fully any fact, any income had escaped assessment.

anchor.surface_text: there is nothing to show that there was any relevant material before the Incometax Officer before he issued the notices under S. 34  1   a  to-have reason to believe that as a result of the assessees failure to state in its return truly and fully any fact, any income had escaped assessment.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Department's sole contention of undervalued 1955 land sale to brothers-in-law lacks shown basis; follows Chhugamal Rajpal requiring relevant material, not vague feelings.

holdings.text: As seen earlier the cash credit entries were brought to the notice of the Income-tax Officer before the relevant assessment orders were passed. He had an occasion to investigate into them.

anchor.surface_text: As seen earlier the cash credit entries were brought to the notice of the Income-tax Officer before the relevant assessment orders were passed. He had an occasion to investigate into them.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cash credits in account books already examined by ITO, with assessee's explanations substantially accepted by appellate authorities and final assessments per 1954 settlement; no omission or failure to disclose.

precedents.citation: Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Com- panies District 1. Calcutta and anr.  1

anchor.surface_text: In Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Com- panies District 1. Calcutta and anr.  1  this Court laid down  1  that to companyfer jurisdiction under s. 34 to issue numberice in respect of assessments beyond the period of four years, but within a period of eight years, from the end of the relevant year, two companyditions had to be satisfied.

precedents.case_name: Calcutta Discount Co. Ltd. v. Income-tax Officer, Companies District 1, Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: To confer jurisdiction under s. 34(1)(a) for issuing notice beyond four years but within eight years from end of relevant year, ITO must have reason to believe (i) income chargeable to tax escaped assessment and (ii) such escapement due to assessee's omission or failure to disclose fully and truly all material facts necessary for assessment.

precedents.citation: Chhugamal Rajpal v. S. P. Chaliha and ors.  1

anchor.surface_text: In Chhugamal Rajpal v. S. P. Chaliha and ors.  1  this Court ruled that before an Income-tax Officer can be said to have had reason to believe that some income had escaped assessment, he should have some relevant material before him from which he companyld have drawn the inference that income has escaped assessment. His vague feeling that there might have been some escape of income from assessment is number sufficient.

precedents.case_name: Chhugamal Rajpal v. S. P. Chaliha
precedents.cited_proposition: Reason to believe escapement of income requires relevant material leading to inference of escapement; vague feeling insufficient. Central Board of Revenue must examine ITO's reasons and arrive at own conclusion before satisfying itself for issuing notice under s.34(1)(a), cannot act mechanically.

precedents.citation: Sheo Nath Singh v. Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax  Central  Calcutta and ors.  2

anchor.surface_text: The same view was again taken by this Court in Sheo Nath Singh v. Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax  Central  Calcutta and ors.  2  In the instant case, the assessee alleged in his writ petitions that there was number relevant material before the Income-tax Officer before he issued numberices under s. 34  1   a  on the basis of which he companyld have had reason to believe that any income had escaped assessment.

precedents.case_name: Sheo Nath Singh v. Appellate Assistant Commissioner of Income-tax Central Calcutta
precedents.cited_proposition: Reiterated the requirements for reason to believe escapement of income and satisfaction of Central Board of Revenue under s.34(1)(a).
